title-group.article-title: Invited Perspective: The All About Arsenic Program—A Blueprint for Leveraging Youth Engagement to Advance Water Justice

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Environmental Health Sciences, Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health, New York, New York, USA

If you need assistance accessing journal content, please contact ehpsubmissions@niehs.nih.gov. Our staff will work with you to assess and meet your accessibility needs within 3 working days.

body.p: Access to safe drinking water is widely recognized as a human right.1 Yet substantial research indicates that US residents reliant on private well water (∼44 million people, ∼15% of the US population) are not afforded this most basic public health protection.2 Although the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulates dozens of contaminants in public drinking water systems, private well water remains largely unregulated.3 Private well owners are responsible for testing their water, installing appropriate treatment systems, and maintaining those systems over time.4–8 Significant socioeconomic inequities in well water testing and treatment persist, leaving low-income well users particularly vulnerable to chronic exposure to water contaminants, including arsenic (As).9–13 For well users, water is a major contributor to total inorganic As exposure.14,15 In New England, elevated geogenic As in underlying aquifers puts thousands of private well users at risk of chronic exposure to As in water at concentrations above the US EPA’s maximum contaminant level (MCL) of 10μg/L. Although some piecemeal efforts by individual states have attempted to remedy the lack of well water testing (such as New Jersey’s Private Well Testing Act),16 substantial coordinated efforts that engage communities are needed to address the environmental injustices facing residents reliant on private wells.17,18

In this issue of Environmental Health Perspectives, Talyor et al. document the success of All About Arsenic (AAA), a school-based program that leverages youth and community engagement to address inequities in drinking water testing for private well communities in New England.19 A collaboration between researchers at academic institutions, state agencies, nonprofits, and local schools, AAA researchers built a vast database of private well water testing results from communities in Maine and New Hampshire by partnering with local middle and high schools. From 2016 through 2022, AAA engaged 32 teachers and 4,859 students from 27 schools in its youth citizen-science program. Teachers assembled water sampling kits, and students collected samples from their homes and communities. Altogether, AAA participants collected >3,000 water samples, more than doubling the amount of publicly available water quality data in multiple participating communities.

The program results underscored the critical importance of accessible well testing for improving the health of private well communities: 24.5% of tested wells (n=752) exceeded New Hampshire’s As MCL of 5μg/L, and 14.8% of wells (n=453) exceeded the US EPA’s MCL of 10μg/L. That is >1,000 households—the homes of community members, children, elders, and families—who would have been protected from elevated water As concentrations had they been connected to public systems.

The success of the AAA program extends far beyond improving private well monitoring inequities and expanding data collection. Students participating in the AAA program also received hands-on training in the scientific research process, including sample collection, data interpretation, and dissemination of results. Students and teachers disseminated findings back to their communities through newsletters, public meetings and displays, and letters to the editor of local papers. Students also testified to the Maine legislature in support of LD1891, HP 1401, An Act to Continue Supporting Safe Drinking Water for Maine Families,20 which provides grants for private well owners to mitigate contamination and cites well water testing results from the AAA program. The bill was passed in 2022.20

The AAA program is a blueprint for how federal investments in environmental health can incorporate established principles of environmental justice, including equal partnership with communities, education and capacity building for future generations, and fair access to resources.21 The substantial federal investments being made in environmental health and justice through the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law22 and the Justice40 Initiative23 are an opportunity to support and prioritize such collaborations that center on communities and youth while leveraging the strengths of academic, nonprofit, and government institutions. In our own work with the Environmental heAlth sciences Research for Teachers and High school students (EARTH) program,24 we can attest that engaging youth in community-based research programs can produce incredibly innovative and creative science. Through the EARTH program, we collaborate with Missouri Breaks Industries Research Inc. (MBIRI), an American Indian–owned company serving the Northern Plains, to provide high school students and teachers with an opportunity to conduct high-quality, locally relevant research in their communities. For example, our students have pioneered research efforts to evaluate the impact of climate change on traditional medicinal plants and have conducted extensive air monitoring across their communities. Directly engaging local communities in the research paradigm allows for sustainable multidirectional learning.21

The wheel does not need to be reinvented; the AAA model can be adapted to serve the needs of communities with a variety of other environmental health concerns, including air pollution, extractive industries, industrial contamination, and toxic chemicals in personal care products. The impressive success of the AAA program on influencing public health policy and improving environmental data equity serves as proof that involving youth engagement and community-based citizen science in scientific research programs is well worth the investment.
